narrative: Charles Everett Brownlow Jr., 36, is charged with killing five people in three separate homes and a convenience store over a span of six hours. He was arrested after being chased in a vehicle and on foot. He was convicted and sentenced to death.

Police said Brandon Howell severely beat an elderly couple and fatally shot three neighbors. The couple died a week later. Howell faced a dozen charges, including three counts of first-degree murder. He was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.
weapon: 12-gauge shotgun

narrative: Five men were tortured, beaten, electrocuted and slashed in what authorities said was a contract killing. Members of a Mexican drug cartel were angry over $450,000 that was missing. Four men went to prison.

According to a medical examiner's report, Joel Smith, 33, had sought help for anxiety but was not taking antidepressants because he had lost his insurance. Smith shot his wife, stepson and two children before killing himself.
weapon: 12-gauge shotgun

narrative: Sonny Enrique Medina, 36, shot Maria Navas, 29, and their three daughters, ages 10, 6 and 2, then himself. Navas had talked about leaving her common-law husband, according to a police report. She was found with numerous bruises on her arms and face.

The Santa Barbara County sheriff said dispatchers received a call from a man who calmly told them he had just stabbed his parents and two sons at the home they all shared. Nicholas Holzer was convicted and sentenced to life.
weapon: Stabbing - Kitchen knives(2)

narrative: Police originally described the slayings of a couple, their daughter and a family acquaintance as a murder/suicide. But six days later authorities charged the couple's adult son, Ryan Champion was charged with four counts of murder in the shootings. He was convicted and sentenced to life.
weapon: .45-caliber semi-automatic handgun

narrative: A 27-year-old woman, her new boyfriend and her parents were found buried a mile from their home. Her former boyfriend, who lived with the family, has been  charged.
weapon: .45-caliber semiautomatic handgun, blunt object.

narrative: Don Charles Spirit called police to say he had killed his adult daughter and six grandchildren, ages 3 months to 11 years, and planned to kill himself. Authorities had investigated the family for child abuse and neglect charges 18 times from 2006 to 2014.
weapon: .45 caliber handgun. As of Sept. 23: "Federal, state and local officials are investigating how he obtained the weapon."

narrative: The bodies of two adults and two young boys were found in their home.
weapon:
The World Journal, October 2014 (Chinese langauge newspaper in NYC's Chinatown)  reports that victim Li's father shared autopsy report with World Journal reporters and it stated, "a knife and a hammer were used, causing head and facial fractures."  State Polce would not comment or release details of the autopsy report.



Initial reports said victims were shot, now various sources have reported they were either stabbed or died from blunt force trauma.

narrative: Shanynthia Gardner, reportedly suffering from mental illness, stabbed her children and superficially cut herself. Her seven-year-old son managed to escape and alert the authorities.
A 15-year-old used text messages to draw several cousins and friends to his cafeteria table at Marysville-Pilchuck High School. He shot five, four of them fatally, before killing himself.
weapon: Beretta PX4 Storm .40-caliber semi-automatic handgun, bought legally and registered to killer's father

narrative: A 9-year-old girl survived a gunshot to call police about a shooting that left five dead at a Wade Park home. James E. Henderson was arrested six months later and charged with aggravated murder. He was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.
weapon: 9mm semiautomatic handgun

narrative: Six people were killed at three locations in suburban Philadelphia. After a daylong manhunt, police found the body of suspect Bradley William Stone, a former Marine, in the woods near his home. Stone's ex-wife and five of her family members died.

Maksim Gelman was sentenced to 200 years in prison in connection to a daylong string of stabbing attacks and carjackings. Four people died and four were injured. A manhunt for Gelman ended when police arrested him in Times Square.

Authorities responding to shots fired at a rural residence found a man dead in the front yard and a woman and two teenagers shot dead inside. An 8-year-old boy was taken to the hospital. Four offenders were arrested and charged with murder.

A dispute over how to run the family limosine business ended with Driss M. Diaeddinn shooting his two brothers, mother and sister-in-law at home. His wife and children escaped. Diaeddinn held police at bay for hours before committing suicide.
weapon: Semi-automatic handgun

narrative: A fire set to a one-room trailer concealed a mother and three young children stabbed to death inside. Authorities had gone to the home twice the day before because of a domestic dispute. Husband and father Jonathan Camacho has been charged with murder.

Thomas Jesse Lee pleaded guilty but mentally ill to five counts of malice murder in the slayings of his wife, her parents, her daughter and a family friend. Their bodies were found at a home where Lee had been staying. Lee is sentenced to life in prison.
weapon: four out of five victims shot with a  .22 caliber handgun

narrative: Police found eight people shot, seven fatally, in four homes at a rural crossroads. Police said they suspected Joseph Aldridge, 36. He was soon found dead of a self-inflicted gunshot in his pickup truck on a road about 15 miles east.
weapon: .45-caliber semiautomatic handgun

narrative: A meeting between five biker gangs at a restaurant escalated into a shootout that killed nine gang members and wounded 18. Police arrested 177 people and found more than 300 weapons, including an AK-47. Officers received and returned gunfire in the melee. After four years, the murder charges were dropped.

Michael Augustine Bournes killed his wife and toddler inside their remote cabin, then went outside and shot his two young sons. He brought their bodies inside, lay them down together, and then set the building on fire and shot and killed himself.
weapon: .45-caliber semi-automatic handgun

narrative: Sixteen-year-old Jordyn D. Wade and Robert Lee Adams Jr., 27, are charged with murder and kidnapping. Two men and two women were killed; another woman was injured. Adams fled the state, but was arrested months later in Mississippi. Adams was convicted and sentenced to life without parole. Wade was convicted and sentenced to 172 years.

Four Marines and a Naval officer died when a gunman attacked a military training center after having shot up a military recruitment office earlier. Mohammod Youssuf Abdulazeez, 24, was killed by a police officer at the scene.
weapon: AR-15 semiautomatic rifle
situation_details: Targeted military recruting center and another U.S. Navy facility

narrative: Police were preparing to arrest Martin Martinez in connection with the 2014 death of his 2-year-old son when they were called to a home and found Martinez' former girlfriend, her mother, and three children - including Martinez's infant daughter - dead.
weapon: Knife

narrative: The bodies of a woman and her three children were found decomposing inside their fire-damaged home. It was unclear when they died. Medical examiners determined the woman had been strangled to death and the children died from smoke inhalation.

Deputies arrested David Conley on capital murder charges after a standoff at a home he once shared with a woman he dated. The woman, her husband and six children were found dead inside. Conley faced earlier assault charges against the same female victim.

Jody Herring, 40, was tackled by onlookers after social worker Lara Sobel was shot dead outside a state office building. Sobel had handled a case involving Herring's daughter. Hours later, three of Herring's relatives were found shot dead in their home.
weapon: Remington Model 700 -  270 caliber bolt-action rifle.

narrative: Four people were shot dead in a car that had been set on fire; two of the victims were in the trunk, and the other two were in the backseat.

Three women and a man were found shot "execution style" in a home on the northwest side of Indianapolis. Police said someone had forced entry, and that the killings were not random. Nicholas Dunn, 36, was arrested in 2019.

Five family members were found dead in their home. Authorities said Brian S. Short, 45, killed his wife and teenagers before killing himself. Acquaintances and family members said Short was depressed because his Internet business was struggling.
weapon: A day or two before Brian Short shot and killed his wife, three children and himself, he bought a Remington 12-gauge shotgun from an Eden Prairie Gandar Mountain outdoors store.

narrative: Police say Glenn Edward Baxter, 27, deliberately drove his estranged wife's SUV into a suburban lake, with Danica Baxter, 25, and the couple's three young children seatbelted inside. The whole family drowned.
Michael Scott, 59, and his wife Cathy, 60, along with their aging moms Barbara Scott, 80 and Violet Taylor, 82, were shot to death by an unknown assailant in their mobile home.
weapon: gun

narrative: Police responding to a welfare check found one person dead, and a barricaded gunman in a second home nearby. After several hours of negotiations, police entered and found the suspect dead, along with four others. Police say all victims were related.
weapon: handgun

narrative: Firefighters responding to a house fire in Rochester, N.Y. discovered four victims and quickly determined the house was a crime scene. No further details are available. police are investigating it as a homicide.
weapon: gun

narrative: A 45-year-old Uber driver went on a shooting rampage killing six and seriously wounding two.  According to police, in between the shootings he continued to pick up and deliver passengers to their destinations.
weapon: 9mm semi-automatic handgun

narrative: A man walked into his neighbor’s house with an AK-47-styled rifle and opened fire, killing four. He then fled the scene and killed another man in Montgomery County, Missouri, some 170 miles west of Kansas City, Kansas.
weapon: Ak-47 styled rifle or shotgun, conflicting reports

narrative: A 26-year-old shot and killed his mother, father, and two younger sisters in their family home before being killed by police. The suspect also set the house on fire, impeding police efforts to rescue any potential survivors.
weapon: gun

narrative: A husband shot and killed his wife, her two adopted children from a previous marriage and a neighbor before killing himself during a standoff with police. A 12-year-old girl survived unharmed.

Five friends were shot and killed by a friend who then set the house they were staying in on fire. Peacock told investigators he had gone out to get everyone breakfast and when he returned the house was in flames. However, he was convicted and given a life sentence.
weapon: gun

narrative: A man shot and killed five people in two locations as a result of a domestic dispute before taking his own life as police closed in.  Some of the victims were reportedly members of his estranged wife's family, though she was not among those killed.
Hopped up on meth, Derrick Dearman drove to a home and killed five (including a pregnant woman), before kidnapping his ex-girlfriend and driving her to a relative's home in MS.
Dibon Toone beat his wife and their children to death, covering their faces with blankets and clothing. He then stole a company car, drove to Virginia, and turned himself in to police.

Six people were killed while camping on one of the victim's newly purchased land. Four men and a six-year-old were shot after getting help pulling their vehicle out of mud; a woman was beaten to death. William Hudson was convicted and sentenced to death.
weapon: gun and blunt object

narrative: A man and his wife, their granddaughter and her three-month-old son, were found shot to death outside their home. Their bodies had also been set on fire. Grayden Denham was arrested and trial is pending.
weapon: Gun and shotgun

narrative: Simmons and Philip were serving long sentences for double homicide (not together) and decided to kill their dormmates because they were annoying, they were bored, and they wanted to get on death row to end being in prison.
A man killed his wife and four daughters before fleeing to Mexico where he was apprehended.  The extradition process is underway. Local police believe a domestic dispute led to the deadly shootings.
weapon: .22 caliber gun – not clear whether it’s a handgun or rife – .22 caliber shell casings were found.

narrative: A dispute between two homeless men living in a vacant building led one of them to start a fire that not only killed the man he intended to kill, but four others as well. Cadaver dogs found the other homeless victims after the fire was put out.
weapon: Fire

narrative: Jacob Kosky and Matthew Baker attended a bonfire party in Jackson, Georgia before returning and killing four.
Dereck Harris shot and killed four members of a family related to a drug debt.

Keith Kroeker shot his wife and three young children before setting their house and barn ablaze and killing himself. No noted stressors, small town, family was known to be very religious (Christian); he was an elder in the church.

Briddell was at Club 66 nightclub with his girlfriend; one of the four victims offered her a ride home, which began an altercation with Briddell, who then open fired on the victim and his friends. No indication that he knew any of them. He was on bail for a similar homicide at a nightclub the year prior.

McVay came to his girlfriend's cousin's house and shot/stabbed four to death, leaving the 3 year old daughter of his girlfriend's cousin alive. He later returned to the scene when police arrived, and pretended to be a normal concerned citizen. Past history of arson and prison, possible domestic violence

Armande was a local druggie/dealer who went to his friend's apartment and killed him after realizing he had used his drugs. He then went to a nearby apartment with other friends, known cocaine dealers, asked to use their bathroom, and then shot them all point blank in the head, presumably stealing the drugs.
Vasquez bludgeoned his wife and two kids to death and stabbed his niece before fleeing to his cousin's house and telling him that he had done something terrible. No other information on motive.
Harris targeted four people after his father was killed the night before, presumably related to gang violence.

Willie Godbolt's wife had left him 3 weeks prior. He went to her mother's house, where she and their two children were staying, to get custody of the kids back. They called the local deputy, which prompted Godbolt to start firing; he killed three family members and the deputy while his wife and children escaped. He then forced two different individuals to drive him around in different cars, and shot and killed four more people in 2 homes. He was shot during the process and claimed that his intention had been suicide by cop. 
Cory Godbolt has been found guilty on all charges: 4 counts of capital murder, 4 counts of first-degree murder, 2 counts of kidnapping, 1 count of attempted murder and 1 count of armed robbery.

After serving time for killing his pregnant wife in 1991, Gregory Green married the daughter of the pastor that had helped secure his release. He later tortured and tied her up, making her watch as he killed their children.

A mother and her two children were missing on April 23rd, 2017. Police found the three of them in different locations, as well as the mother's uncle dead in his home. Her supposed live-in boyfriend confessed to the crimes.

Stanley Ford is accused of setting three fires from 2016 to 2017, including one car fire (no deaths), a house fire that killed 2 adults, and another house fire of his neighbor that killed 7. He is facing the death penalty, but claims he should not be because the police chief used racist terms to describe him on TV.

Neumann was a disgruntled employee that had a previous history of arguing with coworkers, and even had the police called on him at work in 2014 for battering a coworker; no charges were filed. After being fired from his job, Neumann went back to Fiamma Inc and targeted specific coworkers, killing five before himself

Damian Herrera got into an argument with his stepfather about using his pickup truck. He then shot and killed his stepfather, his half brother, and mother when the latter two tried to intervene. His sister escaped. He stole the pickup and fled, eventually killing another man to steal his truck. He then continued to a general store to get gas, and killed another man there as well (unclear if to take his vehicle). He was caught in a police chase that ended in a crash. Currently incompetent to stand trial.

Four assailants broke into the home of a federally-licensed gun salesman (who ran his business from his home), killing the salesman, his wife, and a couple that were visiting to play cards. Robbery was the motive and police believe it was gang related.

Scott Kologi, a 16 year old who was homeschooled by his mother and reportedly had an autism spectrum disorder, killed his parents, sister, and grandfather's girlfriend in their family home on New Year's Eve.
Three known members of the Satan's Disciples gang plus one of their ex-girlfriends were shot in a vehicle by another gang retaliating for a hit two nights earlier. Currently unsolved.
Two offenders killed a friend and her domestic partner as well as their kids to steal an x-box and a TV

Aaron Lawson shot/stabbed four people listed as family members, and stabbed another family member (who survived and alerted police). He raped Staci and was also charged with abuse of a corpse. He was on the lamb when he was arrested.

Alec Perez had repeatedly abused his recent wife, and she had gotten a restraining order against him. He threatened to kill her, and told her he'd be back with the right people. He and Ortiz murdered her and three others.

Joseph Nickell had recently lost his sister to drug addiction, and had a history of substance abuse and domestic violence. He drove to his parent's house, where he killed them, before attempting to kill his son. He then drove 7 miles to his girlfriend's home, and killed her and her mother before committing suicide. Noted interest in guns and was a conservative Christian.

George Davis, on parole, went to a gas station in the morning and got into an argument with the mother of his child, killing her, her passenger, and another male witness. He then went to his cousin's home and killed him before fleeing; he killed himself in Ohio.

Travis Reinking had a history of paranoia and mental illness: he believed that he was being stalked by Taylor Swift and his phone was being hacked; he crashed a pool party in a pink dress (with his rifle in the trunk) before exposing himself to the partygoers; and he attempted to break into the White House to get a meeting with President Trump. After being arrested by the Secret Service, his gun license was revoked, and the guns were turned over to his father. When he wanted to move out of state, his father returned the weapons to Reinking, who used them to kill 4 people at the Waffle House...while naked.
weapon: Used an AR-15 style rifle; after attempting to get into the White House in 2017, his firearms license was revoked, but his father took possession of his four guns, including the murder weapon

narrative: DuPree was friends with the victims and was staying at their house at the time of the murders. He shot the four victims, ransacked the house, and stole their car.

A man was recently estranged from his wife and had lost his local job, working instead out of state. Their oldest son had Williams syndrome. He killed his wife and three young children before committing suicide.

Richard Starry killed two in-laws at a home owned by himself and his father before heading to a local nursing home to kill his father and stepmother and commit suicide. Starry had served 4 years in prison for drug trafficking and had been charged with money laundering (those were dropped however). One sources notes that he became a white supramacist in prison and owned 200+ guns, and suggests that the motive may have been related to a property dispute between father and son.
weapon: one handgun noted

narrative: Ronnie Rodriguez Jr and Sr were at a the birthday party of a one-year-old relative when Juan Espinoza Sr drove by the home. The Rodriguezs confronted him, accusing him of being a peeping tom, and he drove off, returning with his family members. Rodriguez Jr started shooting but missed, and his father grabbed the gun, shooting the five men, killing four and wounding one.
weapon: one handgun

narrative: Cindy Collier had been married for nearly 30 years. In 2007, she separated from her husband, and raised their 7 children alone (3 biological, 4 adopted from China). She was described as a loving, Christian mother who homeschooled her children. She shot and killed her four adopted children, leaving a suicide note, before killing herself. One of her adult biological children found them. In the months prior, she was having some arguments with her estranged husband about custody (during divorce proceedings that were later dropped). She was molested by her parents as a child.
weapon: 34 rounds fired; multiple guns used, at least one shotgun

narrative: Dwight Jones had a history of mental illness and domestic violence. He had used abusive language towards his son, and then beat up his wife. After his arrest for DV, he was court-ordered to undergo a mental health evaluation and was involuntarily committed to a behavioral health facility. After nine years, he posted a YouTube video detailing his beliefs that there was a conspiracy between his ex-wife, psychiatrist, the law firm, and the local government to keep his son away from him. He then killed his psychiatrist, two paralegals who worked for his wife's law firm, a man that happened to be renting the office of a therapist that saw his son, and two friends.

Ian David Long was an honorably discharged Marine Corps vet who moved in with his mother following the end of his service. Neighbors reported that he often fought loudly with his mother, and once called the police because he was acting erraticly. A mental health professional who observed him following this incident suggested that he may be suffering from PTSD, but declined to bring him in for further observation. He was described as a loner by some, and a nice guy by his friends. He had previously frequented the Borderline Bar and Grill on multiple occassions.
weapon: Glock 21 0.45 caliber semi-automatic pistol with laser sight and seven banned HCM

narrative: Two stepbrothers were renovating a house when they found a small stash of drugs. One of the brothers contacted one of the offenders, attempting to sell the drugs. The offenders then attempted to rob the brothers, but wound up executing everyone in the home.

Robert Bowers was a high school dropout who started out as a conservative, but became active in neo-nazi circles online (especially Gab, and worked as an archivist for James Quinn on a volunteer basis). He believed in the white genocide conspiracy theory, made many anti-Semetic and racist remarks and eventually shot and killed 11 people at a synagogue.
weapon: 3 Glock handguns and one Colt AR-15 assault rifle

narrative: In 2011, Jarrod Ramos pled guilty to criminal harrassment of a former high school classmate, and The Capital wrote an article about it. He later filed a defamation lawsuit but lost, and began to harrass the newspaper and specific employees online. He repeatedly posted threats hoping that staff members would die, and at least one staff member attempted to get a restraining order. In 2016, he ceased making threats, but then two years later came to the newspaper's office and shot five before being arrested.

A 27-year-old man entered a Northern Illinois University lecture hall during a class, shot and killed five people and wounded 21 before committing suicide. He was a former student at the university and had a history of mental illness.
weapon:
(From school report; more details in report): Steven Kazmierczak had the following weapons, all 4 purchased from Tony’s Gun & Ammo, 2311 Roland Drive, Champaign, IL.



1. Sig Sauer – 9mm short Kurz pistol with serial number S251262, Model P232

He purchased August 3, 2007 for an estimated $600

2. HiPoint – 380 caliber Model CF380, with serial number P877636

He purchased December 27, 2007 for an estimated $250.

3. Glock 19 – 9mm pistol with serial number LTG682

He purchased February 6, 2008 for $456.95. He picked this weapon up on February 9, 2008.

4. Remington – 12 gauge shotgun, Sportsman 48, with serial number 3009849

He purchased it on February 6, 2008 for $268.21 and picked it up on February 9, 2008.

5. Black lock-blade knife and a small canister of pepper spray

The date-of-purchase information is unknown.



Steven Kazmierczak also purchased three (3) additional firearms from Moser Guns,

located at 9445 Keslinger Road in DeKalb, IL. The dates of those purchases were

February 19, 2007, March 23, 2007 and March 26, 2007.



On August 4, 2007, Kazmierczak purchased a Baikal 12 gauge shotgun, Model IZH

18EM-M, serial number 057714B, from Tony’s Gun & Ammo, located at 2311 Roland

Drive in Champaign, IL. DeKalb Police Department detectives recovered this weapon

at Kazmierczak’s apartment, located at 2108 West White Street, Apartment 137 W, in

Champaign, IL, after the shooting.



Kazmierczak ordered ammunition and magazine pouches from various sources. On

February 4, 2008 he ordered 2 Bianchi Model 20W Tactical Magazine Pouches, Model

15972, for $44.91 each and 2 Glock MF19015 9mm 15-round magazines, for $17.41

each. He ordered them from Able Ammo via its website of www.ableammo.com. They

were shipped to his home address.



On February 4, 2008, he ordered a right-hand Glock holster (BH CRBN FBR GLK 19-

23-32 RH TXTRD) for $34.95 and 2 black Glock Factory Magazines (Glock 17-34, 9mm

blue, 33-round capacities) for $29.86 each. He ordered them from TGSOM, Inc. 1449

S. Broadway Street, Green Bay, WI 54304 via their website of www.topglock.com. They

were shipped to his home address.

narrative: Upset over payroll deductions for child support, Herbert Chalmers Jr. 54, killed his ex-wife and an ex-girlfriend. He took a bus to the caterer where he was considered a good worker and killed the co-owner, her daughter and himself.
weapon: Semiautomatic handgun

narrative: A couple and their two young sons vanished from their home in 2010. In November 2013, authorities discovered their bodies in shallow graves outside Victorville, Calif., and a year later charged one victim's business partner, Charles Merritt, with murder.he was tried and sentenced to death.
weapon: 3-pound Stanley sledgehammer used as a weapon.

narrative: Lovequawn Scott was raised by his grandparents. He did well in school and was liked by classmates. He later played football at two different colleges, but was kicked out for drugs/weapons offenses. It is unclear if Lovequawn had a history of mental illness; he appeared at a church and at an urgent care center where his cousin worked the day before the murders, asking for help. He beat his grandparents, his aunt, and his cousin (who was like a sister to him) to death with dumbbells before being arrested with a hand injury and blood all over him.

Nam Le (Vietnamese) owned a nail salon with his wife, and several family members worked there. He shot and killed his wife, sister-in-law, sister-in-law's fiance, and a family friend/babysitter in his home during a 12 hour standoff with police. Several hours into the standoff, he released his two children (4 and 5) unharmed to the police. He was shot by a sniper and later died at the hospital. No known motive. Everyone seemed to like him and says that they will miss him.
Randy Horn, an amateur boxer and poker enthusiast, killed his wife (27 years his junior), their child, and her two grandparents after posting an ominous message on facebook. No clear motive.

Gamble was on parole, and came to his estranged cousin's home. Without saying anything, he shot his two cousins and his aunt, killing 2/3, and then drove to his best friend's apartment, killing his friend and his friend's girlfriend. He fled to Indiana where he was apprehended. No other details.
The assailant, a former employee of Fedex, entered the facility near the Indianapolis airport and started firing outside and then inside.

Charles DuBois was unemployed, living at home, and had a known drug abuse problem. He had previously suffered from suicidal thoughts, and was taken to emergency psychiatric care two weeks prior to the incident. He intentionally lit two fires at home in the middle of the night while his family slept. He attempted to use the insanity defense but then later recanted it. No motive clear.

A family member found a couple and their three girls shot dead inside their home. The Culpeper County sheriff said the deaths were apparently a murder-suicide resulting from a "domestic situation" between the two adults.
weapon: .380 high point semi-automatic handgun - confimed by Culpeper County Sheriff's Office PIO, Detective Deavers

narrative: Seung-Hui Cho, an "angry and disturbed" Virginia Tech senior, killed two students in a dorm before entering classrooms and shooting others. Thirty-two people died. A review found that Cho's mental health history should have prevented him from buying guns.
weapon: Glock 19 9mm semiautomatic pistol and a Walther P22 .22 caliber semiautomatic pistol - in his backback her carried almost 400 rounds of ammunition most of which were in rapid loading magazines, a knife, heavy chains, and a hammer.

narrative: Hersel M. Isadore Jr., 28, was "depressed and acting irrationally" in the weeks before he fatally shot his longtime girlfriend, four of their children and a cousin, according to a police report. Isadore then commited suicide.
weapon: Revolver
situation_details: Depressed for a long time but "was tired of being being picked on"

narrative: In January 2007, police found the bodies of four homeless men dumped in manholes.They apparently had stolen scrap metal from the suspects. Daniel Joseph Sharp pleaded guilty and is serving a 65-year sentence. Randy Lee Reeder received a sentence of 260 years.
weapon: Hammer-like weapon

narrative: Luke Karpinski appeared to be a loving family man, but he killed his wife and 3 kids before killing himself and lighting their house on fire. Their 2 dogs also died.

Authorities say a family dispute over an inheritance left four family members dead. Felton Bernard received a life sentence in the shootings of his uncles, an aunt and her boyfriend. Corey Berniard was sentenced to 30 years in prison.

Auto mechanic Raymond Oyler, 37, was convicted of setting a wildfire that killed five federal firefighters. The 60-square-mile Esperanza fire also destroyed 54 homes and other buildings. He was sentenced to death in 2009.
weapon: Fire

narrative: Someone twice set fire to a trailer in a mobile home park. On the third try, five of 10 occupants died, in part because the owners had covered windows with wire mesh. They settled survivors' claims for $6 million. The case remains unsolved.

Richard Wilkinson didn't get along with his daughter and son-in-law, who lived with him. He argued with her and told friends they were stealing. One night, he shot them and his two grandsons, ages 3 and 6. As police entered his home, he killed himself.
weapon: 2 handguns.

narrative: Michael Cummins had a history of violence and drug problems. After being released from a year in jail for attempting to burn down his neighbor's house and assaulting her, Cummins violated his parole and was about to be arrested. He killed three family members and his uncle's girlfriend and relatives before attacking another woman, presumably to steal her car. He was found by police in a creek bed by the home, and was shot before being taken into custody.

Gurpreet Singh called 911 ro report that four members of his well-respected Sikh family were found shot dead in their home while preparing food. Two moths later he was arrested for the murders of his wife and three other relatives. The couple's three children were not at home at the time.

Four related men were shot and killed inside an injured victim's home. The police believe the incident was related to drugs, as drugs and weapons were found in the home. The victims knew their attacker, but the case remains unsolved.

Terrance Robinson, 22, went into the house, stayed a few minutes, left briefly and returned to shoot two men and two women, possibly because of an earlier dispute. He was sentenced to eight life terms without the chance for parole.
weapon: “Handgun” – Also, Gunn (witness) admits writing the note that told the woman to give him money, drugs and the ".38 cal gun," but contends Robinson signed it and added his nickname, Sandman." (KC Star) – (FOIA will confirm…hopefully, but they must have found that caliber as the same as murder weapon or why bother? – mh)

narrative: A retaliatory shooting at a Fourth of July street party killed four and injured two others. Antonio D. "Cheem" Williams and James R. Washington were sentenced to life in prison. Rosario C. Fuentez pleaded guilty and got 20 years.
weapon: .45-caliber handgun and 2 SKS AK-47 assault rifles

narrative: Three men and two women were shot in the head and killed during a Chicago burglary. Suspects stole money, jewelry and TVs, police said. Torolan Williams and Michael King were found guilty and face life in prison. Arthur Brown was sentenced to 24 years.

After a lengthy mental evaluation, Everett Conant III was ruled competent. He pleaded no contest to murder in the killings of his three sons and their uncle, and one count of attempted murder in the shooting of his wife. He will serve life in prison.
weapon: Two 9-mm pistols - approx 50 rounds fired -  a shotgun and a semi-automatic rifle were found in the home - Spec. Agt. Len Propps of the Wyoming Division of Criminal Investigation.

narrative: A white gunman killed nine people, including a pastor, attending a prayer meeting at a historic black church. Dylann Storm Roof, 21, was charged with murder and federal hate crimes. He was convicted and sentenced to death.
weapon: Glock .45-caliber model 41 semiautomatic handgun – bought with money given to him by his father in April for his 21st birthday. Law enforcement confirms make and model.

narrative: Hours after police responded to a domestic violence call at the home, the estranged husband shot his wife and her two children, as well as her father. The father survived until Dec. 4, 2015, making his the fourth death. The offender took his own life.
weapon: gun

narrative: Timothy Smith went to a car wash in the middle of the night to engage in a fight with his ex-girlfriend's new boyfriend. While the victims believed it was supposed to be a fistfight, Smith killed them all before committing suicide. It is unclear when he and Chelsie Cline broke up; her sister says a few months prior, whereas the estranged wife of Porterfield says that it was two days prior to the incident. Smith was described as obsessed with Cline, bringing her flowers when she was sick, etc. She had recently posted on facebook that she needed to be taken out on a date or by a sniper, and Smith commented "I can do both."
weapon: Had 3 guns, including 9mm handgun, AR-15 .223 calliber assault rifle, and .308 calliber rifle; did not use the .308 during the attack. Had multiple magazines, was wearing body armor without the ballistic panels inserted, and shot approximately 30 times

narrative: Matthew Murray, 24, was dropped from the missionary program of New Life Church in Arvada, Colo. Five years later, he returned and shot two people then drove 80 miles to the evangelical church itself, where he killed two others before committing suicide.
weapon: Bushmaster X15 .223-caliber rifle, Beretta .40-caliber handgun, Springfield Armory 9mm handgun. Killer fired 26 shots. Also: Left AK-47 in car. Also: .22-caliber Beretta handgun and bomb-making parts found in apartment.

narrative: Christopher Harper-Mercer, 26, opened fire on his writing class at Umqua Community College in rural Oregon, killing his instructor and eight other people before he was wounded by police. He committed suicide at the scene.
weapon: Handgun used in classroom but law enforcement has not yet identified the murder weapon(s) specifically used.  The following weapons have been identified, but it is unclear if these were part of the 6 weapons found with the shooter, or if they are from the weapons cache found at his apartment.  Semi-automatic handgun, .40-caliber Taurus semi-automatic handgun, .556-caliber Del-Ton semi-automatic rifle (AR-15 look) (s).40-caliber Smith & Wesson

narrative: Investigators say Matthew Blixt 17, used his father's gun to shoot his father, his father's girlfriend and the woman's two daughters before turning the gun on himself. Friends said Blixt was upset that his father, separated from his mother, was dating.
weapon: Handgun - HI-Point 9mm semiautomatic handgun (recovered at scene) – the gun was his fathers.  A ballistic analysis found all the expended casings and projectiles found at the scene came from that gun.

narrative: Esteban Santiago-Ruiz was born in NJ but grew up in Puerto Rico; after serving in the National Guard and Iraq, family members said he was a changed person, extremely quiet, withdrawn, and with anger and mental health issues. He moved to Alaska and dated a woman 14 years his senior, having a baby with her, but was arrested for domestic violence against her, after which they continued to live together. He was fired from the Alaska National Guard for poor performance and worked at a security company before being fired for mental health issues. A few months prior to the incident he went to the FBI claiming that the government was trying to control his mind and make him join ISIS; he was given a mental health evaluation. His guns had been taken away a few times previously, but he was currently a legal gun owner and concealed carry permit owner.

Nikolas Cruz had a history of serious mental health and behavioral problems, switching schools multiple times for disciplinary reasons, etc. He attended specialty schools for students with emotional and behavioral problems, and had been recommended to be involuntarily committed by a SRO and counselors. After being expelled from Majory Stoneman Douglas High School, he used an AR-15 style rifle that he had legally purchased to kill students and teachers. He had a history of making threats about killing others, specifically referencing wanting to become a school shooter, and he had been reported to local authorities including the FBI on multiple occassions for these remarks on social media.
weapon: AR-15 style semi-automatic rifle(Smith & Wesson M&P15 Sport 2)

narrative: A 22-year-old college student frustrated over sexual rejections promised in a video to "annihilate" women "on the day of retribution." Elliot Rodger, who was found dead, is suspected of the shootings that killed six and wounded seven others.
weapon: (3) 9mm semiautomatic handguns – (2) Sig Sauer P226 pistols (1), Glock 34 Long Slide – found in the car according to police along with 41 magazines with 10 rounds each - Santa Barbara County Sheriff Bill Brown - all bought legally at local gun stores.

narrative: Police said Jody Hunt, 39, drove to three locations around Morgantown and shot an ex-girlfriend, a cousin and two other acquaintances. He was found that evening in his pickup truck, an apparent suicide. Hunt, a convicted felon, bought his handgun online.
weapon: 9 mm semi-automatic handgun (with shoulder stock) was purchased by another man legally from a licensed dealer 4 years ago. Hunt, a convicted felon, purchased it from that man online. Sheriffs declined to prosecute the man because he didn't know Hunt was a felon.

narrative: Four children, their mother and grandfather died in a house fire that critically injured their father. Court documents say Ryan Williams was angry that the father had turned him in to police on a theft charge. Williams was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.

Reginald Hester had made a deal with a woman living in an apartment building to have sex for $10. After taking his money, the woman went back into her apartment and did not come back out, so Hester started a fire that killed four.

Offender planned the attack for almost a year; moved from Uzebekistan where he was an accountant after winning Green Card in 2010; got married, had kids, worked for Uber. Rented a truck from Home Depot and drove into bike lane to hit riders/pedestrians. Claimed it was for ISIS.

Devin Kelley had a history of warning signs, including DV, sexual assault, prison time, military experience and obsession with weapons, obsession with previous mass shootings, restraining order, treatment in a mental health facility, etc. He went to his wife's family's church and killed 25, including her grandmother. A citizen exchanged gunfire with him and pursued him, so he committed suicide and crashed his car.
notes: One of the slain victims was pregnant, which explains why some accounts indicate 26 victims killed.

narrative: Returning after having bought marijuana, Parks and an accomplice, both armed, ordered everyone in the home to take off their clothes and hand over cellphones, money and jewelry, prosecutors said.  They then discovered a woman in a back bedroom with a cellphone and became "agitated," they said. The two "started executing the victims by shooting them in the head as they were lying on the ground," according to a court document detailing the charges. Four victims died at the scene. There were two survivors of the shooting. One escaped by playing dead and was able to later identify Parks. The other, Shacora's teenage daughters, remained on life support, unable to respond to touch or sound, until she died more than 10 months later.

A month after being fired from his brother's moving firm, Edwin Rivera, 20, shot and killed his father, two brothers and a police officer during a standoff at his home. He was killed by a police sniper's bullet as he fled a fire caused by stun grenades.
weapon: .380 caliber pistol, 32 Magnum Charter Arms revolver/pistol and a 12-gauge Savage Arms double-barreled shotgun – found in home but not near gunman’s body.

narrative: A woman and her boyfriend stand accused of killing her parents and then shooting her brother and his family as they arrived for Christmas Eve dinner. Michele K. Anderson and Joseph Thomas McEnroe both were sentenced to life without parole.
weapon: 9 mm handgun and .357 Magnum revolver

narrative: Paul Devoe is sentenced to death in the shootings of four in Texas. Just before killing his ex-girlfriend and others, he killed two and injured one in Pennsylvania. He initially was found incompetent to stand trial, but after medication was deemed fit. He was then convicted and sentenced to death.
weapon: .38-caliber semiautomatic handgun

narrative: Ricky Gray, 28, was convicted of murdering a family of four during a burglary. His nephew, Ray Dandridge, 28, assisted. A week later, both men killed a family of three. Dandridge was convicted in that case and was given a life sentence. Gray also confessed to murdering his wife and sentenced to death.
weapon: razor knife and "claw" hammer

narrative: Police say a custody battle may have sparked the fatal shooting of eight people at a beauty salon. Scott Dekraai pleaded guilty in May 2014 and sentenced to life without parole in the slayings of his ex-wife and others, including a man parked outside the shop.
weapon: 9 mm Springfield, Smith & Wesson .44 Magnum, Heckler & Koch .45-caliber

narrative: Matthew Locke apparently killed his cousin's wife, Sara, and his cousin's children, while Moses Bermudez (said cousin) was working out of state. No motive has been offered, but the police initially charged him with lying about an investigation, as he claimed that Moses had insinuated that MS-13 was responsible for the murders. He also apparently lied about his relationship with Sara (not sure yet what that relationship was) and was in possession of drug parapernalia despite being on parole.

Seven people were shot or stabbed in a Forsyth County farmhouse. Four died. Convicted: Jason McGhee, sentenced to life without parole; and Frank Ortegon, sentenced to 20 years in prison.  Marcin W. Sosniak was sentenced to life without parole.
weapon: Walther P99 .40-caliber pistol S&W/11 round mag (Serial # - 462553)– knives too

narrative: Damian Jordan had a history of violence against women, with multiple arrests for battery. He pleaded guilty to four counts of manslaughter in the shootings of two sisters and their children. Jordan was sentenced to 80 years in prison.
weapon: "Semi-automatic pistol" - "Deputy Superintendent Marlon Defillo said ballistics tests already confirm that the semi-automatic pistol found in Jordan’s possession was the gun was used in the massacre. Now detectives want to find a definitive DNA link between the gun and Jordan. “The ballistics match on the gun, but I have to put the gun in his hand,” Defillo said. “The witnesses are all dead, so we’re going to have to win this case on forensics.” (WWL-TV Channel 4 - March 29, 2010)

narrative: Gary Martin had a long history of domestic violence, and had been in prison for stabbing an ex-girlfriend in 1995. He was able to apply successfully for an Illinois FOID card due to the lack of fingerprinting, but failed to secure a concealed carry permit, and was sent a letter indicating that he had to give up his guns and FOID card. It remains unclear if the police ever followed up on his illegal gun ownership. After working at Henry Pratt company for 15 years, he went to a meeting where he was told he was being fired. During the meeting, he shot his coworkers/boss, and hid in the 29,000 sq ft factory until police found him, and exchanged gunfire, killing him.
weapon: Martin applied for an IL FOID card in 2014 and received one, because IL does not require fingerprinting. When he later applied for a concealed carry permit, he was rejected due to his felony assault in MS, and was sent a letter requiring him to relinquish his handgun and FOID card. Unclear if the police ever followed up. The gun was a Smith and Wesson 0.40 caliber with a laser scope

narrative: An unnamed 9-year-old was arrested for intentionally setting fire to a mobile home, killing five members of his family, including three children. The boy's mother says her son suffers from schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and ADHD, and takes medication daily
weapon: Fire

narrative: Javier Casarez's 28-year marriage ended four months prior when he believed that his wife was cheating on him (potentially with two of the male victims). His ex-wife claimed a history of verbal abuse, and asked for spousal and child support in addition to the family home. Casarez presumably forced his ex wife to go to his workplace, where he killed her and two others before driving to the home of a man that had loaned him money in 2010, killing that man and his daughter. The young children in the home were unharmed. He then carjacked a mother and child, telling them that he is "not a bad guy" before letting them go. When confronted by police, he committed suicide.
weapon: Smith and Wesson 500 0.5 caliber handgun, legally purchased in 2004

narrative: Investigators at first thought four children and their mother had died in an accidental house fire. But they discovered the kids had been killed -- three had slashed throats -- and Leisa Jones, 30, died of smoke inhalation.
weapon: Straight razor, fire

narrative: Adrian Burks went to the house where his girlfriend was staying, got in an argument and killed her and the other three people who lived there, including a 3-year-old girl. He pleaded guilty to the four shootings and received life in prison.
weapon: "Long black gun"

narrative: Wade M. Page, 40, lead guitarist in a white-power band named End Apathy, entered a Sikh temple in Oak Creek, Wis., and killed six with a handgun. He wounded three, including a police officer. After police shot Page in the stomach, he killed himself. One of the injured died eight years later from complications related to the injuries.
weapon: Springfield Armory XDM 9 mm handgun purchased legally at a gun shop in West Allis, Wisc.

narrative: The bodies of 40-year-old Deirdre Zaccardi, 11-year-old Alexis Zaccardi, 9-year-old twins Nathaniel and Kathryn Zaccardi, and 43-year-old Joseph Zaccardi were found by a relative inside their townhouse. All five appeared to have been shot. It has been determined that Joseph Zaccardi, killed his wife and children before killing himself.  According to Joseph’s Facebook, he was out of work, with his employment listed as “Unemployed and Going Crazy.” Recent posts on his Facebook profile showed that he had written and illustrated four self-published children’s books, with the most recent, “Day is Done No More Fun,” published in June 2018.
notes: The Medical Examiner confirmed this to be a murder-suicide.

narrative: Following a long-standing dispute with a co-worker, Anthony Ferrill shot and killed 5 fellow employees at the Milwaukee facility of the Molson Coors Beverage Company GeForce turning the gun on himself. Reportedly, he felt that he was being harassed by other on the job.
weapon: two handguns, one with a silencer

narrative: Seven family members found dead in an apparent murder-suicide. The shootings took place in neighboring homes.

Dakota Theriot had a "violent streak" and a known problem with drugs. Two weeks prior to the incident, he was kicked out of his parents' trailer for his drug problem, and went to live with Summer Ernest, his girlfriend of a few weeks, with her family. It appears that there was some sort of dispute, and he killed his girlfriend and her family (but let her two young siblings live) before stealing their car, driving to his parent's house, and killing them. He then drove to his grandmother's home, where police apprehended him during a wellness check (she called in afraid he would come for her next).

Desmond Turner, 28, and James Stewart, 30, were convicted of shooting seven family members in an attempted robbery and burglary at a home. The gunmen mistakenly believed that the family had drugs and money. Turner was sentenced to life in prison without parole, plus 88 years; Stewart, to 425 years.
weapon: Evidence technicians recovered 23 discharged 7.62x39 mm cartridge casings from the scene. These cartridges accommodate high velocity caliber bullets used in AK-47 and SKS-type assault rifles. A witness saw Turner with a long gun and Stewart with a handgun, but it doesn't appear any handgun bullets were recovered at the scene.

narrative: Five teens were shot to death while sitting in a car. The suspect maintained his innocence and plead guilty to lesser crimes after his case was overturned. Now prosecutors have a new suspect.
weapon: .40-caliber semiautomatic handgun – 32 round magazine – 27 shots fired (27 Aquila .40-caliber S&W shell casings found at scene)

narrative: Four children -- ages 3 to 8 -- died in a Cleveland house fire set by a man who was angry at their mother, a former girlfriend. Lorenzo Collins, 42, was sentenced to 111 years in prison. Collins Bennett, 39, his accomplice, also was convicted and given a 16 year sentence.
weapon: Fire

narrative: Jared Lee Loughner went to an event for Rep. Gabrielle Giffords and shot her and constituents waiting to speak with her. Six died and 13 others, including Giffords, were hurt. Loughner pleaded guilty in 2013 to avoid the death penalty and was sentenced to life.
weapon: 9mm Glock 19 semiautomatic pistol, at least 2 30-round magazines

narrative: Three brothers and a cousin were shot on their patio while watching a Los Angeles Lakers game on TV. Police have said the shooting is gang-related. It has not been solved.
weapon: Semiautomatic Rifle – Press accounts have it as a “semiautomatic weapon”. PIO says it was a “high-power rifle” and another press account says, firing was “continuous.” If the rifle were a shotgun or hunting rifle (non-semiautomatic weapons) , firing would not be “continuous”) – Team concurs with labeling this weapon a “semiautomatic rifle”

narrative: A birthday party ended in violence when a woman's estranged husband burst into her house and shot her, her boyfriend, and two members of her family, police said. Guillermo Lopez, 48, set his truck and home on fire before he killed himself.
weapon: semi-automatic handgun - Reuters

narrative: A woman called police to report that she heard "someone got shot." Responding officers found four men dead inside the house. Police said the shooting did not appear to be random, but have made no arrests.

An itinerant man is charged with stabbing his cousin's wife and her four children after briefly staying with the family. Police found Mingdong Chen at the scene covered in blood. Chen pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 125 years to life in prison.
weapon: Meat cleaver

narrative: Arson trapped a mother and her two kids in an apartment building. Another woman died jumping from the fourth floor. Six years later, prosecutors charged Samuel Martinez with murder but have cut his bail to $1 and said they may seek dismissal of charges.

The police receive a 911 call from the person believed to be the assailant. Upon arriving at the home, officers found five victims fatally shot.  In addition, young child was found alive in the house, and investigators believe the shooter decided to spare the infant's life. The suspected shooter, who had a criminal record with level offenses, was arrested.
weapon: 12-gauge Mossberg shotgun

narrative: An ex-husband dressed up as Santa Claus and went to his former in-laws' home during a Christmas Eve party. He shot and killed his ex-wife and members of her family before setting the house ablaze. Nine died. The killer committed suicide.
weapon:
Total: (5) Sig-Sauer Model P226 semiautomatic 9mm handguns - 4 left at scene; 1 taken with Pardo offsite.  Lt. Tim Doonan, Covina Police Department.



Of those 5, Autopsy report confirms make, model, caliber and serial number of two.  

 (1)Sig-Sauer Model P226 semiautomatic 9mm handgun, serial number U777822. one round in the chamber, 15 in the magazine. Luger +P 9mm jacketed hollow point bullets.

(1)Sig-Sauer Model P226 semiautomatic 9mm handgun, serial number U459976. One round in the chamber, magazine empty.

(3) Sig-Sauer Model P226 semiautomatic 9mm handguns – two left at scene and one taken offsite



Incendiary Device - Home-made high-octane racing fuel spraying. No ignition device onboard.  Pardo had sprayed racing fuel, intending to ignite it with a flare. But flames in two fireplaces triggered an explosion. He was severely burned.

narrative: An oilfield worker killed the mother of his child, then went across town to kill her brother, mother and mother's boyfriend. Omar Kalmio, 27, spared his infant daughter. He will remain in prison for life without the chance for parole.
weapon: 9mm semiautomatic handgun - no gun found but shell casings at crime scene confirm same gun fired all.

narrative: A domestic shooting turned public when the gunman left home, carjacked a woman, shot at other vehicles, and then entered the campus of Santa Monica College with a semi-automatic rifle. Police shot John Zawahri, 23, in a standoff in the school's library.
weapon: a .223-caliber AR-15-style assault rifle - looks like a Bushmaster - spare barrel; .44-caliber revolver, 20 magazines loaded with 1,300 rounds of ammunition, boxes of extra bullets, and wearing a tactical vest (bullet-proof)

narrative: Leonard Egland killed his estranged wife, her boyfriend and the man's son. He took his own daughter, 7, to Bucks County, Pa., killed his mother-in-law, dropped his daughter at a hospital, wounded two policemen, escaped and killed himself that night.
weapon: Semiautomatic rifle fired at SWAT teams, handgun flashed at hospital orderly

narrative: Police said that Cedric Prather approached his ex-wife's home and began shooting. He killed her and another man and two children and wounded two more children before shooting himself fatally.
weapon: ".45-caliber handgun"

narrative: Holmes was recently divorced with three children and was unemployed despite having a college degree in criminal justice. She went to three separate locations to kill her recent boyfriend, sister, and mother/stepfather.

DeWayne Craddock, a 15-year employee with no criminal history, submitted his two weeks notice to the Virginia Beach Municipal Government citing "personal reasons." He then went on a rampage at work a few hours later, killing 12 and injuring 5.
weapon: 0.45 caliber ACP pistols (two), suppressor, and HCM found near shooter; unconfirmed reports of a rifle, legally obtained

narrative: Responding to complaints of an odor coming from an abandoned home, the police discovered the bodies of four gunshot victims. Because of the extent of decomposition, the date of death could not be determine. Two of the four victims have been identified. The location was known as a drug house.
weapon: Unidentified gun

narrative: Late on a Saturday night, neighbors heard pounding on a door, then the sound of someone breaking in, then gunshots. Police found the bodies of a woman, her two young sons and her boyfriend.

Jones killed his wife (allegedly during an argument) and the four children on what is believed to be July 10, 2019. Then on September 15, 2019, after crashing his van in Brantley County, GA, he told responding officers that his dead wife was in the back of the vehicle. He then told police about their children whose bodies were left in wooded area in Charlton County, GA, off Hwy. 301. All five victims (wife, 2 stepsons, and 2 daughters) were apparently killed weeks earlier in the family residence. T
weapon: Jones killed his wife with a baseball bat
notes: The ex-wife of Michael Jones was told by Jones that he and his current wife, Casei, were getting a divorce and asked to stay at her home in Jacksonville.

narrative: A radicalized Islamic married couple opened fire at a holiday office party in San Bernardino, Calif., killing 14 and injuring 21. They were shot dead by police later that afternoon; an arsenal of weapons, ammunition and bombs were found in their home.
weapon: (1) DPMS .223 semi-automatic rifle; (1) Smith & Wesson MMP15 .223 semi-automatic rifle; (1) Smith & Wesson 9mm semi-automatic handgun; (1) Llama semi-automatic handgun;  Thousands of rounds of ammo for both on their person, in their rented SUV and at their home.  At the IRC there were three pipe bombs attached to a remote-controlled toy car.   Their home also contained 8 pipe bombs and parts and tools to make more.

narrative: A plan to steal marijuana and cash from a home ended in the shootings of two women, a baby and a toddler. Five men were convicted in connection to the robbery and slayings. The accused shooter, Ronald Davis, was sentenced to 245 years.
weapon: Handguns – TEC-9 handgun 9mm (Frazier) and a Glock .40 caliber (Davis) (Appeals-Court Doc)

narrative: Six members of a military family, including four young children, were found dead in their car in the family’s garage in San Antonio, apparently after suffering from intentional carbon monoxide poisoning, the police said on Thursday. It isbeing investigated as a murder-suicide.  The husband and wife in their mid-to-late 30s and four children, ranging in age from 11 months to 4 years were discovered along with two cats found dead in a basket in the front seat.
weapon: Noxious chemical

narrative: Seven people, all of Laotian descent, were fatally shot at a residence authorities believe was being used "to manufacture and harvest an illicit marijuana operation."Six of the victims were killed at the scene and a seventh was hospitalized and died later the same day. Sheriff Chad Bianco said all seven victims were of Laotian descent and that the illegal marijuana growing and processing operation was run by a local Laotian organized crime syndicate he believes is based in the United States.

Three adults and two children died when the fire swept through their two-story home in the Green Valley Ranch neighborhood in northeast Denver at about 2:55 a.m. on August 5, the authorities said.
Three teenagers were arrested months later and charged with murder, burglary, assault, and arson. The sister of one of the accused was also arrested on Ferrer allegations Gun and drug charges.
weapon: Fire

narrative: According to authorities, 25-year-old Mickey Dane Douglass, while out on parole for robbery conviction, claims someone made a comment about his gym shoes that made him feel threatened. He shot four people, three of whom died at the scene and a fourth died days later from his injuries.
Four cousins were shot to death allegedly by the former fiancé of one of the victims (Laura Tanner) who'd previously been accused of domestic violence.

Nine people were shot, four fatally, at a private bar (the Tequila KC Bar)  in Kansas City. The incident appears to have been precipitated  by the bartender's refusal to serve one of the two assailants. 

Police said that the shooting may have been motivated by an earlier dispute at the bar, and that Villanueva-Morales and Javier Alatorre allegedly returned afterward and carried out the shooting.
 While authorities have not determined the motive, information is coming to light about the two suspects' ties to vast criminal networks.
weapon: Handgun

narrative: Officers were called to 537 Willow Park Road just after 8:00 a.m. on July 29, 2020 for a welfare check. When they arrived, they found five people dead inside the house. All five sustained what appeared to be gunshot wounds.  In what appeared to be a murder-suicide,  44-year-old John Nelson fatally shot his wife and three children before turning the gun on himself. It is believed that the deaths occurred on July 28.
weapon: Gun

narrative: A crowd initially gathered on the street Friday for an unrelated Juneteenth celebration. Crowds gathered again nightly through Sunday, and police said there were about 400 people on the scene when shots rang out at about 12:30 am early Monday morning. Three victims were initially reported dead and a fourth died a day later at the hospital. A total of 181 shell casing were found at the scene.
Seven people were shot, four of them fatally, in a hail of gunfire in Paterson, NJ after 11 pm in what has been called a gang-related incident.
Conducting a welfare check, Lauderdale County deputies found three bodies at a residence and another at a nearby location. The assailant killed himself during pursuit by law enforcement.

A pharmacy robbery ended with David Laffer shooting four people, including two store employees, before fleeing with 10,000 hydrocodone pills. His wife, a painkiller addict, drove the getaway car. Laffer received four life sentences without parole, and she received a 25 year sentence for her role.
weapon: .45-caliber handgun

narrative: Five female were found dead in an apparent murder-suicide.  The five were  identified Patricia Patrick, 61; Jaquita Chase, 31; Abigail Heflin, 12; Levenah Countryman, 10; and Danielle Collins, 7. The relationship of the victims was not disclosed, though authorities described the killings as "domestic related." There has also been no report of which was the offender.
Brittany Tucker fatally shot her neighbor and then went back to her apartment and shot and killed four of her children. She then committed suicide.
weapon: Gun

narrative: Five adults, one of whom was pregnant, were found dead inside a residence. Investigators were led to the crime scene after making contact with a juvenile male, whose age police didn't disclose, who was found nearby suffering from gunshot wounds.
weapon: Two handguns. A 9-millimeter handgun and a Draco firearm

narrative: Four people were killed and four wounded in a shooting in Englewood on the South Side. They were at a large gathering in the street about 11:35 p.m. in the 6100 block of South Carpenter Street when four males walked up and started shooting, according to Chicago police.
weapon: Gun

narrative: Stephen Paddock, a multimillionaire professional gambler, set up shop in the Mandelay Bay hotel and open fired on concert goers, killing 60 (two of whom died years later from their injuries.  Of the 867 injured victims, 411 were injured by gunfire.

State police found two adults and two children; the adults were shot while the children died of smoke inhalation from the fire, apparently set to cover up evidence of the murders. The assailant was convicted and given a life sentence.
weapon: gun and fire

narrative: On July 8, 2019, Johnson shot and killed Collins inside her residence before setting the house on fire and fleeing the scene.  Johnson returned to the crime scene early the following morning and shot and killed Cousin, Collins’ neighbor, in a vacant field adjacent to his residence.
The assailant shot seven victims, four of them fatally, During a four hour rampage that started in Chicago and ended in Evaston, wher he was shot dead by police.

An 18-year-old Alaska man just out of jail for assault has been charged with killing four members of his family. The shootings occurred at two locations about 30 minute drive apart. A 6-year-old was apparently spared during the early Monday morning shooting spree north of Anchorage because of defective bullets.
weapon: Glock

narrative: Two teenagers (A male and a female) fatally shot for victims in their home. it appears that the victims were the male’s family.

A 21-year-old Georgia man was arrested in the killings of eight people at three Atlanta-area massage parlors, six of them women of Asian descent. According to authorities, the assailant, Robert Aaron Long, had previously visited the two Atlanta spas. Long claimed he was a sex-addict and was trying to eliminate temptation.
notes: Two additional shooting sites were in Atlanta. By rule, the location of the majority of victims is used. Five victims (four killed, one injured) were at the Cherokee County site.

narrative: Rescue units responding to a house fire found four bodies inside. All, including two children, had been shot. Police arrested James Bannister, one victim's boyfriend, who is charged with four counts of murder. He was convicted and given a life sentence.
weapon: Murder Weapon: .38 caliber or .357 caliber handgun - "The scene was later searched by deputies, detectives, and forensic personnel, and projectiles were recovered from the home. These projectiles were examined by FDLE and were determined to have been fired by either a .38 caliber or .357 caliber handgun, both of which are typically revolvers." - from Probable Cause Arrest Affidavit -Police still looking for the weapon.A witness stated: "The defendant admitted that the murder weapon was a .38 caliber weapon, and that he had since disposed of that weapon."

narrative: Police received reports of a gunman firing shots from a car at several locations in Springfield. The vehicle crashed into the Kum & Go gas station and convenience store and the gunman ran inside and began shooting. The first two officers who arrived were shot. The fatalities  included three customers,  one police officer, and the assailant. The assailant, Joaquin Roman, was mentally ill, according to his mother.  According to one of the surviving victims,  Roman gave a half-gibberish speech about being disrespected throughout his life and wanting to inflict pain on others. There was evidence that Roman had searched online for "mental illness" and "tactical shooting" a few days before the attack.
weapon: Glock 9-mm handgun and an SKS 7.62-caliber rifle — the two guns police say Roman used during his shooting spree. Police say Roman obtained the guns legally.

narrative: • Ten people, including a Boulder police officer, were killed in a shooting at the King Soopers supermarket in Boulder, Colorado.The suspect was taken into custody and was treated for injuries.
notes: Reported an Ruger AR-556  rifle and a semi-automatic.

narrative: A woman injured by gunfire directed the police to a home where they found four people, including a child, shot dead. The woman was taken to a hospital in stable condition. Police indicated that the incident was the result of a disagreement in the home that escalated to gunfire. Reportedly, the dispute involved the COVID-19 stimulus check. The assailant wanted half of the $1,400, but the the woman who survived a gunshot refused to share that much.

Deputies responding to a call about a shooting found seven people dead inside a home that had been set afire. Investigators believe the victims, three women and four men, were shot. The victims and offenders were part of a club called "Seven Deadly Sins." It is report that the two suspects went to the house to “wipe the slate clean” because several personal firearms were missing and there had been “perceived disobedience” toward a local membership club.  Neighbor said house known for heavy drug activity. Suspects and victims were involved in a club called "Seven Deadly Sins.” It is believed the shooting  involved a dispute between members of a local group called the “7 Deadly Sins” motorcycle club.
notes: It is suspected that the victims were involved in drug trade.

narrative: Oreanna Myers shot her five children, set the house on fire, and went outside and killed herself. The investigation subsequently concluded that it was murder-suicide.

A plan to steal drugs from an acquaintance ended in his killing and the slayings of his wife and three children. Charles W. Gilleo Jr. received five life sentences without parole, while Mark S. Serrano was sentenced to 50 years to life.
weapon: Weapon(s): Remington Model 522 Rifle, .22-caliber, Serial # 3224142 (sawed-off), Knife, Blunt Force Object. Rifle purchased at Dick's Sporting Goods, Poughkeepsie, NY - Cost: $139.99 - Federal Firearm License # 6-14-014-01-BJ-34901

narrative: A week after losing his medical job, Ervin Antonio Lupoe, 40, killed his wife and their five children in their home located in the Wilmington neighborhood of LA city. He then committed suicide. In a note, Lupoe wrote that he and his wife, who also lost her job, had agreed to the killings.
weapon: Revolver

narrative: Jessie Dotson, out of prison five months for an earlier murder, was convicted of killing his brother and five others, including two toddlers. Dotson was sentenced to death. Three young children were badly injured. The older two testified against Dotson.
weapon: Handgun - semi-automatic handgun/knife/"board" – guns never found but 9mm and .380 shell casings and "jackets" found in the victims or at the crime scene, according to Tennessee Bureau of Investigation’s testimony. (Memphis Commercial Appeals Trial Blog).    http://blogs.commercialappeal.com/memphis_trial_blog/2010/10/tbi-firearms.html

narrative: Two children were among the victims of a shooting in what police described as a "known narcotics location." All four victims were shot as they slept. Patrick Albert Young Smith was found guilty of four counts of murder and sentenced to life in prison.
weapon: Assault rifle

narrative: Aaron Huff, 28, attended a Seattle rave and an after-party at a house, then left. He returned with a handgun and a shotgun that he used to kill six people before killing himself. He left an assault rifle in his car.
weapon: Winchester Defender pump action 12-gauge shotgun with pistol grip, Ruger semi-automatic P-94 handgun .40 caliber, Bushmaster AR-15 assault rifle in vehicle (not used), two bandoliers with 15 rounds of 12-gauge 00 buck shotgun shells each, 2 extra .40-caliber magazines on his belt.  He also wore a tactical ammunition pouch filled with AR-15 ammunition for the Bushmaster in his truck.  The murder weapons had been confiscated by Montana police 6 years earlier after he shot at a statue of a moose, but were later returned to the suspect.

narrative: Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, an Army psychiatrist, has been sentenced to death in the Fort Hood shootings. He entered a military medical center firing a semi-automatic pistol, killing 13 and injuring 32. The FBI has called it a case of workplace violence.
weapon: FN Herstal 5.7 semi-automatic pistol, (so-called Cop Killer gun) and a .357 revolver(not fired according to investigators).

narrative: A woman, 27, was shot in her home. Her three children -- ages 3, 5 and 10 -- were strangled or suffocated. A former boyfriend, named as a suspect by police, is in prison on a unrelated murder charge. He becomes eligible for parole in 2050.

Three years after disability retirement for psychological problems, Jennifer Sanmarco, 44, killed a former neighbor. She then returned to her postal workplace to fatally shoot six people before killing herself, all with a legally purchased handgun.
weapon:
Handgun - Smith & Wesson model 915 - 9mm with 15-round capacity. 



Handgun purchased at Ace Pawn and Antiques in Grants, N.M., and an unspecified amount of ammunition from a pawn shop in Gallup, N.M., said Santa Barbara County Sheriff's Department, sheriff's Sgt. Erik Raney



Paul Castillo, owner of the pawn shop, said San Marco bought the gun for $325. The gun originally was purchased by another person in San Jose and later sold to the pawn shop, Raney said.

narrative: A couple and their two sons were killed at milepost 149 on the Florida Turnpike in a drug trade case. Gunmen Daniel Troya, 23, and Ricardo Sanchez Jr., 23, are on death row. Their boss, Daniel Varela, 26, is serving two life terms plus 60 years.
weapon: .40-caliber handgun and 9mm handgun - "St. Lucie County Sheriffs Office firearm and toolmark analyst Mark Chapman told jurors he believed the bullets had several unique markings that matched the .40-caliber and 9mm bullets recovered at the scene of the slayings." (Palm Beach Post (Florida) February 24, 2009)

narrative: Henry Lee Stringer, then 34, torched a house, killing his two young kids. Firefighters also found their mother and grandmother fatally stabbed. He accepted life in prison without a chance for parole to avoid the death penalty but offered no explanation.

Jason "J.T." Ready, a well-known white supremacist who had run for public office, shot his girlfriend, three of her family members and then himself. In February, police told Ready's girlfriend to get a protective order against him; she declined.
weapon:
Beretta 9mm Semiautomatic handgun – murder weapon



Home Weapons Cache: 



Raven .22-caliber Semiautomatic handgun



Camouflaged CMMG Model 45A (AR15-styled) semiautomatic rifle with grenade launcher with spare grenades - Serial #5A20876



Black Mossburg Shotgun Serial #P740985



.22-caliber Rifle



Camouflaged Modified AR15 .223-caliber semiautomatic rifle with MWG Grip



Bushmaster AR15 Model XM15-E28 .223-caliber semiautomatic rifle - Serial #BF1648593

narrative: Nikolay Lazukin shot his wife and two daughters, suffocated his infant and set the house ablaze. He also used a baseball bat to kill a neighbor who was walking nearby. Lazukin killed himself after sending an apologetic text message to his father-in-law.
weapon: .380-caliber semiautomatic handgun, baseball bat (Matlock),suffocation (infant)

narrative: Hector Celaya was in a lengthy custody dispute involving his three children. He shot his mother, two uncles and son on the Tule Indian Reservation before fleeing with two daughters. Before he was shot by police, Celaya shot both girls, killing one.
weapon: Rohm RG38 .38-caliber revolver - 6 round capacity - Originally shipped to Alamo Leather Goods, March 30,1979, 16101 College Oak Drive, San Antonio Texas - now out of business. No information tying killer with weapon purchase (ATF Firearms Trace Report)

narrative: Using two handguns, Michael Hance went on a shooting spree, killing seven neighbors and relatives of his live-in girlfriend. His girlfriend was injured in the attack. Police fatally shot Hance outside a suburban home 10 minutes after the shooting began.
weapon: Hi-Point .45 ACP, .357 Magnum Revolver. Legally purchased at a Barberton, Ohio, pawn shop (Sydmor's Jewelry) a week earlier

narrative: Aunterrio Barney was arrested in North Carolina months after a purposely set fire killed three adults and a 2-year-old boy. Barney had faced the death penalty, but because Illinois has banned it, he now will serve a mandatory life sentence.
situation_details: Enraged at one of the victims for not returning calls, believing she was with another man

narrative: Rick Odell Smith, 43, was shot by police shortly after the slayings of five family members. Smith carried an injured 6-year-old next door and asked neighbors to take her to the hospital. He had been in a custody dispute with a relative of the victims.
weapon: Winchester 20-gauge pump-action shotgun, murder weapon - in vehicle: .270 bolt-action Winchester rifle with a scope, a Ruger carbine rifle and a Gerber Gator machete that according to the firm's website has an 18-inch blade on one side and an 18-inch "high performance" saw blade on the other, Monique Bond, Illinois State Police said.

narrative: After finding a woman in an alley with gunshot wounds, police found her car and then her house half a mile away, where her brother, ex-husband and another woman lay dead of gunshots. The first victim died two days later. No arrests have been made.
weapon: Undetermined gun(s)

narrative: A 67-year-old woman and her daughter, granddaughter and great-grandson were found after a house fire. They had been stabbed or died in the blaze. Alexander Hill Jr., who was arrested a year later in Buffalo, was charged with four counts of murder. He was convicted and sentenced to life.
weapon: Two victims stabbed with knife, 2 died of smoke inhalation
situation_details: Offender's girlfriend lived with the victims but wasn't present during the incident

narrative:
Officers responding to a 911 call about a shooting encountered an armed suspect at the house, The suspect,  fled on foot after an officer fired but missed. Pridgeon
was caught after a short pursuit.
Found dead inside the house were the suspect's brother and four children, police reported. Another child died after being taken by air to a hospital in Tulsa. 

The children's mother, Brittany Anderson, suffered life-threatening injuries in the house and was taken to a Tulsa hospital, police said. She was reported to be in stable condition. Three other children in the home were not injured, police said.

Police arrested Daron Dylan Wint, whose DNA was found on a pizza crust inside the home of a local CEO. Authorities believe the CEO, his wife, 10-year-old son and housekeeper were held captive before they were killed and their house set ablaze. 
 The prosecution had maintained that the motive for the gruesome murders was greed. All four victims were killed despite a $40,000 ransom being dropped off at the home by an assistant of Savvas's. Wint had thousands of dollars in cash in his possession when he was arrested.  Wint was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.
weapon: Bloody baseball bat admitted into evidence.
